Description: Pointed ovoid mould-made pottery oil-lamp with splayed flat-topped nozzle with a curved tip. The filling-hole is surrounded by a raised ring rim. Raised angle with impressed point on nozzle-top. Circular raised base. Brown Nile silt fabric. Rude work.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A similar, but finer, unprovenanced Egyptian parallel in the British Museum, is dated to the 1st century BC (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q598). Parallels dated late 2nd century BC to 1st century BC, based on examples from Athribis, though parallels from other sites may be later (Mlynarczyk 1997, 74, Type L, Fig. 116, Photo 20). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.053) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4852 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
